content.title: Stroke Prevention (Secondary Prevention)
content.summary: Evidence-based strategies to prevent recurrent stroke after ischemic stroke or TIA
key_points: Antiplatelets for non-cardioembolic stroke; anticoagulation for cardioembolic (AF)
High-intensity statin for all atherosclerotic strokes
DAPT for 21-90 days after high-risk TIA/minor stroke
Address modifiable risk factors: smoking, diabetes, obesity

statement.text: Secondary stroke prevention is tailored to stroke mechanism: antiplatelets for non-cardioembolic, anticoagulation for AF, high-intensity statins for atherosclerotic disease, blood pressure control, carotid intervention for significant symptomatic stenosis, and aggressive risk factor modification.
statement.formal: Stroke Prevention = Mechanism-specific treatment (antiplatelet vs anticoagulation) + Statin + BP control + Carotid intervention if indicated + Lifestyle modification

explanation.intuition: Preventing a second stroke is about understanding why the first one happened and blocking that pathway. If it was a clot from the heart (AF), blood thinners are key. If it was from a narrowed neck artery, fix the narrowing. If it was from small vessel disease, control blood pressure.
explanation.key_insight: The first 90 days after stroke/TIA carry the highest recurrence risk. This is when aggressive, mechanism-specific therapy has the greatest impact. Long-term, risk factor modification (especially BP and smoking) provides sustained benefit.

definitions_glossary.secondary_prevention: Preventing recurrent stroke after index event
definitions_glossary.antiplatelet_therapy: Aspirin, clopidogrel, or combination to prevent arterial thrombosis
definitions_glossary.anticoagulation: DOACs or warfarin for cardioembolic stroke prevention
definitions_glossary.carotid_endarterectomy: Surgical removal of atherosclerotic plaque from carotid artery
definitions_glossary.carotid_artery_stenting: Endovascular stent placement as alternative to CEA
definitions_glossary.cryptogenic_stroke: Stroke without identified cause despite workup; consider PFO, occult AF
definitions_glossary.modifiable_risk_factors: HTN, DM, smoking, obesity, dyslipidemia, physical inactivity
definitions_glossary.ESUS: Embolic stroke of undetermined source - subset of cryptogenic
definitions_glossary.patent_foramen_ovale: PFO - atrial septal communication allowing paradoxical embolism
definitions_glossary.paradoxical_embolism: Venous thrombus crossing PFO to arterial circulation causing stroke

pathophysiology.recurrence_risk: Without treatment: 10-15% at 1 year; with optimal prevention: 3-5%

mechanism_specific.atherosclerotic: Plaque instability → antiplatelets, statins, BP control
mechanism_specific.other: Dissection, hypercoagulable, vasculitis → treat underlying cause

antiplatelets.DAPT: Aspirin + clopidogrel × 21-90 days for high-risk TIA/minor stroke (CHANCE, POINT)

anticoagulation.indication: Cardioembolic stroke (AF, mechanical valve, LV thrombus)
anticoagulation.DOACs: Apixaban, rivaroxaban, dabigatran, edoxaban - preferred for AF
anticoagulation.timing: Start after imaging confirms no hemorrhagic transformation (typically 2-14 days based on infarct size)

statin_therapy.benefit: Reduces recurrent stroke, MI, vascular death

carotid_intervention.timing: Within 2 weeks of event for maximum benefit
carotid_intervention.CAS: Alternative for high surgical risk; similar outcomes for most

PFO_closure.indication: Cryptogenic stroke age <60 with high-risk PFO features
PFO_closure.trials: CLOSE, RESPECT, REDUCE showed benefit over medical therapy alone

definition.@value: Evidence-based strategies to prevent recurrent stroke after ischemic stroke or TIA, including mechanism-specific therapy and risk factor modification

learning_objectives: Select antiplatelet vs anticoagulation based on stroke mechanism
Apply DAPT for high-risk TIA/minor stroke
Know indications and timing for carotid intervention
clinical_pearls: DAPT × 21-90 days after high-risk TIA reduces recurrence by 25% (CHANCE, POINT)
Don't delay carotid intervention - benefit greatest within 2 weeks
BP control is most impactful long-term modifiable factor
Smoking cessation reduces stroke risk by 50%
Young cryptogenic stroke: consider PFO closure if high-risk features

sources.source: Kleindorfer DO, et al. 2021 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guideline. Stroke 2021
